block.p: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Reprise Room at Dillon's, 245 West 54th Street, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes, which focuses on what Mr. Comstock calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, whose creamy baritone echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Tonight and Monday through Wednesday nights at 8; tomorrow at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sunday night at 7:30. Tickets: $50 and $55; premium ringside seating, $75 and $80 (Stephen Holden).
A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Reprise Room at Dillon's, 245 West 54th Street, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes, which focuses on what Mr. Comstock calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, whose creamy baritone echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Tonight and Monday through Wednesday nights at 8; tomorrow at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sunday night at 7:30. Tickets: $50 and $55; premium ringside seating, $75 and $80 (Stephen Holden).

MARC SALEM, Feinstein's, at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. Marc Salem is the mental magician who dazzled audiences at the Westside Theater with his 1997 show, ''Mind Games.'' Now Mr. Salem, accompanied by a trio of bass, piano and percussion, is in residence at Feinstein's with ''Mind Games and All That Jazz.'' But handsome as it is, Feinstein's at the Regency may not be the ideal setting for the display of Mr. Salem's enjoyable bag of tricks. The intimacy of Feinstein's, where Mr. Salem seems to be working with a smaller palette than at the Westside Theater, detracts from the aura of magic that can surround, say, a wristwatch that suddenly changes the time it displays. The jazz trio Vibrations, as pleasant and talented as it is, provides little more than a few attractive introductory numbers and a bit of musical commentary of the ''Twilight Zone'' sort. Nevertheless, Mr. Salem and his wizardry provide cool fun for hot summer nights. Friday and Saturday nights at 8:30 and 11; Sundays at 1:30 p.m.; Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8:30. Cover: $40 on weekends; no cover on weekdays; dinner required for early show on weekends, with seating beginning at 6; a la carte supper menu with $20 minimum for late show; $35 for early show; Sunday brunch is $30 and cover is $30. Through Sept. 2 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

ARCI'S PLACE, 450 Park Avenue South, at 30th Street, (212) 532-4370. Christiane Noll, singer, in an evening of jazz, with David Budway, pianist. Tuesday through Friday nights at 9; Saturday nights at 8:30 and 11. Through Sept. 2. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. KT Sullivan, singer, in ''Dancing in the Dark,'' the music of Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz; with Wes McAfee, pianist; John Loehrke, bassist. Sunday and Monday nights at 8. Cover: $25; $15 minimum.

BEMELMANS BAR, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. Peter Mintun, pianist. Tuesday through Saturday nights beginning at 9:30. Through Oct. 14. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $10. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.

CARNEGIE CLUB, 156 West 56th Street, (212) 957-9676. Cary Hoffman, with the 11-piece Carnegie Club Orchestra, plays music made famous by Frank Sinatra in the 1950's, featuring the original arrangements by Nelson Riddle. Friday and Saturday nights at 9:30 and 11. Cover, $20; two-drink ($15) minimum.

CAFE PIERRE, Fifth Avenue at 61st Street, (212) 940-8195. Friday and Saturday nights from 8:30 p.m. to 12:30; Tuesday through Thursday nights, 8:30 to 11:30, Kathleen Landis, singer-pianist, in ''Fascinating Rhythms: 50 Years of American Popular Song and Jazz, 1900-1950.'' Sunday and Monday nights from 8:30 to 11:30, Nancy Winston. No cover; $20 minimum.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight at 7, Will Parker, singer; from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Jerry Scott. Tomorrow from 5 to 9, Chuck Musone; at 7, ''Four by Four,'' with Gerte Grunen, Aaron Morishita, Carol Shedlin and Charles Wallrich singing works of Kurt Weill, Jule Styne, Richard Rodgers and Cole Porter; from 9 to 1, in the piano bar, Mr. Scott; at 9:15, Nikayah Blackman. Sunday night from 7 to 11, Sol Yaged and friends. Monday night at 7, ''Four by Four''; from 8 to midnight, in the piano bar, Chris Barrett. Cover: free to $12; $10 minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 6, Parker Scott, singer, with Gerry Dieffenbach, pianist; at 8, Katherine Albis, singer, with David Lewis, pianist; at 8, Erin Gibson, comedy characterization; at 10, Richard Skipper impersonates Carol Channing; at 11, Ron Seykell, Broadway singer, with Lenny Babbish, pianist. Tomorrow night at 6, Elizabeth Robinson, singer, with Warren Chaisson, pianist; at 6, ''What a Piece of Work Is Dan!,'' musical comedy revue; at 8, Sharon McNight and Louis Goldberg, singers; at 8:30, ''Poole Party!''; at 11, Tommy Femia impersonates Judy Garland. Sunday night at 8, Laura Burkell, singer, with Richard Danley, pianist; at 8, ''Camp Adrianne for Girls,'' comedy with Adrianne Tolsch. Cover: Free to $18. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

FIREBIRD CAFE, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. Tonight at 9, Perry Payne, singer, in ''Do You Know What It Means to Miss New Orleans?'' Cover: $20; $15 minimum. Tomorrow night at 9, Natalie Douglas, singer, in ''Not That Different.'' Cover: $20; $15 minimum. Tomorrow night at 11, Alton F. White, singer, in ''How Do I Feel?'' Cover: $30; $15 minimum. Sunday night at 7, Ronny Whyte, singer-songwriter and pianist. Cover: $20; $15 minimum.

JOE'S PUB, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Tonight at 8:30, Queen Esther in ''Unemployed Superstar,'' a solo show about pop culture. Tickets: $12. Sunday night at 9, Eszther Balint, singer, songwriter and avant-garde experimentalist. Tickets: $12.

OAK ROOM, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. Jay Leonhart, jazz songwriter and bassist, with Bill Charlap, pianist, and Michael Leonhart, trumpeter. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $40, with dinner required for early shows; $15 food or drink minimum for other shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Leslie Orofino, singer, opens on Tuesday in ''Summer Wishes.''

TRIAD, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 279-4200. ''Berlin to Broadway With Kurt Weill,'' musical revue; with Lorinda Lisitza, Bjorn Olsson, Michael Winther and Veronica Mittenzwei. Friday, Monday, Tuesday and Thursday nights at 8; Saturdays and Wednesdays at 3 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $45.

UPSTAIRS AT ROSE'S TURN, 55 Grove Street, West Village, (212) 366-5438. Tonight at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Tomorrow night at 9, ''Me, Him, Her and the Other Guy''; at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Sunday at 5 p.m., Susan Neuffer, singer. Cover: $6 to $10; two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
